text: - Hi, I'm Aarthi from AWS.
- Hi, I'm Carlos Carlos from Oportun,
and 'This is My Architecture'.
- We've got an architecture here,
but I would love to understand,

what business challenge
are you trying to solve
with AWS solutions?
- So the business challenge
that we were trying to solve at Oportun
was knowing where our sensitive data was.
It was vastly important for us to know,

especially sensitive data
for our members' information
to protect it.

That was a number one challenge
that we wanted to solve.

- Help me understand
what kind of data is it,
and why is it important to Oportun?
- We provide financial services to folks,

so that typically are left
out of financial mainstream.
Our members' data is very important to us,
so things like social security numbers,
ITINs, government IDs, right?

All this information is what
we need to provide services
to our members,

and it is of utmost importance
to us to protect that data.

- Awesome, so why don't you
show us how you utilize Macie
to achieve this.
- Sure.
Yeah, so Macie is a data discovery tool.
And the main thing about Macie is,
you know, you can connect multiple.

Most organizations have more
than one AWS account, right?
We started, from our perspective,
priority was production data,

you know, we connected
our production accounts.

And for every account
that you connect Macie to

you have an S3 bucket
that you have to set up
for that account.
Once we connected Macie to our accounts,

it quickly did an inventory
of all our S3 buckets,

and it was just a matter
of, you know, us determining

which buckets we wanted
to scan out of the box.

You know, the end result,
really, is to improve

our data security posture
management, our DSPM.

Improve and protect our
customer data is the end goal.

So when we run these scans
on the S3 buckets, right?
And we're running our scans,
whether they're manual or scheduled
or whatever cadence we have,
we have findings that are coming in here.
Again, as I mentioned,

no PII, no sensitive
information is in the buckets.
- [Aarthi] So, basically, just metadata.

- It's metadata, and these
are S3 buckets that we own,
they're in our account, right?
That's important as well,

because ultimately, the
results come in here,

you know, again, it's the
number of SSNs in this bucket
or number of ITINs or date of births,
whatever it is that you're looking for,
depending on the sensitivity of the data.

So you have the data that
goes into the buckets,

and we have other tools,
you know, services with AWS
such as Amazon Athena here
that looks into and queries these buckets.

Amazon Athena is a SQL-based
discovery query tool

that basically looks at the
information from the findings.

And to your point about
what are we doing with this,
ultimately, the end result is identifying

the findings there, finding
the owners of the buckets,
and then ultimately remediating, right?
How do we remediate?
We identify the owners.

Additional services
that we have, you know,
in our use case, we drop the data as well

into some MySQL data
lake that we've built.
And you don't wanna give users,
yeah, a big CSV file or Excel file with,
"Here, here's all your findings."
You wanna tell a better story.
We do that by peering into,
you know, the information directly

from the S3 bucket via Athena
and putting that information
in a dashboard using QuickSight,
other tools like Tableau, Power BI,

you know, whatever analytic
tool that you have,
any business intelligence tool
to tell a better story of saying,
"Hey, here are our top 10, top 20, top 30,
risky buckets by type of PII,

and here's the owners that
we wanna remediate with."

And that's how we go and talk
to the owners, remediate,

we show them, and we work
together to remediate,
delete the data, archive it,

remove the bucket if it's
no longer in use, right?
Glue is also part of that equation,
but primarily, it's the process
of Amazon sending the findings to Athena
and via some automations with Glue.

We have the additional
processes that get the data,
load the data, aggregate it,
and then we ultimately report it
and talk to our data owners.

- But on an average, what would
you say the accuracy is like
for something landing into a bucket,
being detected by Macie, and then going

through your like
visualization workflow here?
- Yeah, so, you know,

for patterns and RegExes
like SSNs and ITINs,

some of those top really
critical sensitive types,
our accuracy we found

with Macie automated
sensitive discovery was 95%.
- Got it.
Thank you, Carlos, appreciate sharing
the architecture with us.
- You're welcome, thank you for having me.
